Understand the 'Veggie ID' Concept:**<br/>'Veggie ID' is an online quiz that categorizes users into vegetable personalities like Jalapeno or Napa Cabbage, based on their choices in an interactive story set in VeggieVille. Each personality type comes with strengths, weaknesses, and catchphrases. Since its launch, it has attracted over two million users, with significant participation from Singapore. ([straitstimes.com](https://www.straitstimes.com/life/st-picks-what-s-your-veggie-id-the-personality-test-craze-sweeping-s-pore?utm_source=openai))<br/><br/>**3. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Katong_laksa?utm_source=openai))<br/>  - **Hainanese Curry Rice:** A comforting dish with a mix of flavors, symbolizing a balanced and adaptable character. + const resultsScreen = document.getElementById(&#39;results-screen&#39;);
+ const startBtn = document.getElementById(&#39;start-btn&#39;);
+ const restartBtn = document.getElementById(&#39;restart-btn&#39;);
+ const questionText = document.getElementById(&#39;question-text&#39;);
+ const optionsContainer = document.getElementById(&#39;options-container&#39;);
+ const progressFill = document.getElementById(&#39;progress&#39;);
+ const resultContent = document.getElementById(&#39;result-content&#39;);
+ 
+ // Event listeners
+ startBtn.addEventListener(&#39;click&#39;, startQuiz);
+ restartBtn.addEventListener(&#39;click&#39;, restartQuiz);
+ 
+ function startQuiz() {
+     startScreen.classList.remove(&#39;active&#39;);
+     quizScreen.classList.add(&#39;active&#39;);
+     currentQuestion = 0;
+     scores = { &#39;I&#39;: 0, &#39;E&#39;: 0, &#39;N&#39;: 0, &#39;S&#39;: 0, &#39;F&#39;: 0, &#39;T&#39;: 0, &#39;J&#39;: 0, &#39;P&#39;: 0 };
+     showQuestion();
+ }
+ 
+ function showQuestion() {
+     if (currentQuestion &gt;= questions.length) {
+         showResults();
+         return;
+     }
+ 
+     const question = questions[currentQuestion];
+     questionText.textContent = question.question;
+     optionsContainer.innerHTML = &#39;&#39;;
+ 
+     question.options.forEach((option, index) =&gt; {
+         const button = document.createElement(&#39;button&#39;);
+         button.className = &#39;option-btn&#39;;
+         button.textContent = option.text;
+         button.addEventListener(&#39;click&#39;, () =&gt; selectOption(option.personality));
+         optionsContainer.appendChild(button);
+     });
+ 
+     // Update progress
+     const progress = ((currentQuestion + 1) / questions.length) * 100;
+     progressFill.style.width = progress + &#39;%&#39;;
+ }
+ 
+ function selectOption(personalityTypes) {
+     // Score each personality type
+     personalityTypes.forEach(type =&gt; {
+         // Extract dimensions from personality type
+         if (type[0] === &#39;I&#39;) scores[&#39;I&#39;]++;
+         if (type[0] === &#39;E&#39;) scores[&#39;E&#39;]++;
+         if (type[1] === &#39;N&#39;) scores[&#39;N&#39;]++;
+         if (type[1] === &#39;S&#39;) scores[&#39;S&#39;]++;
+         if (type[2] === &#39;F&#39;) scores[&#39;F&#39;]++;
+         if (type[2] === &#39;T&#39;) scores[&#39;T&#39;]++;
+         if (type[3] === &#39;J&#39;) scores[&#39;J&#39;]++;
+         if (type[3] === &#39;P&#39;) scores[&#39;P&#39;]++;
+     });
+ 
+     currentQuestion++;
+     
+     // Add a small delay for better UX
+     setTimeout(() =&gt; {
+         showQuestion();
+     }, 300);
+ }
+ 
+ function determinePersonality() {
+     const personality = 
+         (scores[&#39;I&#39;] &gt; scores[&#39;E&#39;] ? &#39;I&#39; : &#39;E&#39;) +
+         (scores[&#39;N&#39;] &gt; scores[&#39;S&#39;] ? &#39;N&#39; : &#39;S&#39;) +
+         (scores[&#39;F&#39;] &gt; scores[&#39;T&#39;] ? &#39;F&#39; : &#39;T&#39;) +
+         (scores[&#39;J&#39;] &gt; scores[&#39;P&#39;] ? &#39;J&#39; : &#39;P&#39;);
+     
+     return personality;
+ }
+ 
+ function showResults() {
+     quizScreen.classList.remove(&#39;active&#39;);
+     resultsScreen.classList.add(&#39;active&#39;);
+ 
+     const personality = determinePersonality();
+     const dish = personalityDishes[personality];
+ 
+     resultContent.innerHTML = &#96;
+         &lt;div class=&quot;result-card&quot;&gt;
+             &lt;div class=&quot;dish-emoji&quot;&gt;${dish.emoji}&lt;/div&gt;
+             &lt;h2&gt;You are ${dish.name}!&lt;/h2&gt;
+             &lt;p class=&quot;personality-type&quot;&gt;${personality}&lt;/p&gt;
+             &lt;p class=&quot;dish-description&quot;&gt;${dish.description}&lt;/p&gt;
+             &lt;div class=&quot;traits&quot;&gt;
+                 &lt;h3&gt;Your Traits:&lt;/h3&gt;
+                 &lt;div class=&quot;trait-tags&quot;&gt;
+                     ${dish.traits.map(trait =&gt; &#96;&lt;span class=&quot;trait-tag&quot;&gt;${trait}&lt;/span&gt;&#96;).join(&#39;&#39;)}
+                 &lt;/div&gt;
+             &lt;/div&gt;
+             &lt;div class=&quot;share-section&quot;&gt;
+                 &lt;p&gt;Share your result with friends!&lt;/p&gt;
+             &lt;/div&gt;
+         &lt;/div&gt;
+     &#96;;
+ }
+ 
+ function restartQuiz() {
+     resultsScreen.classList.remove(&#39;active&#39;);
+     startScreen.classList.add(&#39;active&#39;);
+ }
+ 
```

</details>

</tool-use>

- # letsmakan
+ # Let&#39;s Makan! üçú
+ 
+ A gamified personality test that matches you with a Singaporean dish based on the 16 MBTI personality types. Inspired by the [Vegetal](https://github.com/sophie006liu/vegetal) personality test.
+ 
+ ## About
+ 
+ Discover which iconic Singaporean dish represents your unique personality! Answer a series of questions and find out if you&#39;re a bold Chilli Crab, a comforting Laksa, a strategic Bak Kut Teh, or one of 13 other delicious Singaporean dishes.
+ 
+ ## Features
+ 
+ - üéÆ Interactive quiz with 10 engaging questions
+ - üçú 16 Singaporean dishes mapped to MBTI personality types
+ - üé® Beautiful, modern UI with smooth animations
+ - üì± Fully responsive design
+ - ‚ö° Fast and lightweight
+ 
+ ## Personality Types &amp; Dishes
+ 
+ | Personality Type | Singaporean Dish | Description |
+ |-----------------|-----------------|-------------|
+ | INTJ | Bak Kut Teh | Strategic, independent, complex |
+ | INTP | Kaya Toast | Analytical, innovative, precise |
+ | ENTJ | Chilli Crab | Bold, ambitious, commanding |
+ | ENTP | Rojak | Creative, energetic, unpredictable |
+ | INFJ | Laksa | Insightful, empathetic, deep |
+ | INFP | Ice Kacang | Idealistic, creative, layered |
+ | ENFJ | Hainanese Chicken Rice | Charismatic, caring, unifying |
+ | ENFP | Satay | Enthusiastic, social, warm |
+ | ISTJ | Char Kway Teow | Reliable, practical, traditional |
+ | ISFJ | Bak Chor Mee | Warm, dependable, caring |
+ | ESTJ | Nasi Lemak | Organized, efficient, complete |
+ | ESFJ | Popiah | Sociable, caring, wholesome |
+ | ISTP | Hokkien Mee | Practical, hands-on, straightforward |
+ | ISFP | Oyster Omelette | Artistic, flexible, unique |
+ | ESTP | Black Pepper Crab | Bold, action-oriented, spicy |
+ | ESFP | Murtabak | Spontaneous, fun-loving, energetic |
+ 
+ ## Getting Started
+ 
+ Simply open &#96;index.html&#96; in your web browser to start the quiz!
+ 
+ No installation or dependencies required - it&#39;s a pure HTML, CSS, and JavaScript application.
+ 
+ ## How It Works
+ 
+ 1. Answer 10 questions about your preferences and behavior
+ 2. The quiz scores your responses across the four MBTI dimensions:
+    - **I/E**: Introversion vs Extroversion
+    - **N/S**: Intuition vs Sensing
+    - **F/T**: Feeling vs Thinking
+    - **J/P**: Judging vs Perceiving
+ 3. Get matched with your Singaporean dish personality!
+ 
+ ## License
+ 
+ This project is open source and available for personal and educational use.
+ 
+ ## Credits
+ 
+ Inspired by [Vegetal](https://github.com/sophie006liu/vegetal) by sophie006liu - a personality test that matches users with vegetable identities.

---


Created a personality test game similar to Vegetal. Here's what's included:

## What I've Built

1. **HTML Structure** (`index.html`)
   - Start screen with welcome message
   - Interactive quiz interface with progress bar
   - Results screen showing your dish match

2. **Quiz Logic** (`quiz.js`)
   - 10 questions covering MBTI dimensions
   - Scoring system that determines your 4-letter personality type
   - 16 Singaporean dishes mapped to each personality type:
     - INTJ ‚Üí Bak Kut Teh
     - INFP ‚Üí Ice Kacang
     - ENFP ‚Üí Satay
     - And 13 more!

3. **Styling** (`styles.css`)
   - Gradient design
   - Smooth animations and transitions
   - Responsive layout for mobile and desktop
   - Hover effects and interactive elements

4. **Documentation** (`README.md`)
   - Project overview
   - Complete mapping of all 16 personality types to dishes
   - Instructions for use

## Features

- No dependencies ‚Äî pure HTML, CSS, and JavaScript
- Interactive quiz with 10 questions
- Progress tracking
- Animated results with emoji and descriptions
- Trait tags for each personality type

Open `index.html` in your browser to try it. The quiz asks about preferences and behavior, then matches you with a Singaporean dish that represents your personality type.

Want any changes to the questions, dish mappings, or styling?

The quiz should have opened in your browser. Here are a few ways to test it:

## Method 1: Direct file open (what we just did)
- Double-click `index.html` in Finder, or
- Right-click ‚Üí Open With ‚Üí Your browser

## Method 2: Using a local server (recommended for development)
If you prefer a local server, you can use Python's built-in server:

---



---


A local server is running. Open your browser and go to:

**http://localhost:8000**

This serves the quiz from a local server, which can help avoid some browser security restrictions.

## Testing the Quiz

1. Start screen: click "Start Quiz"
2. Answer 10 questions: select an option for each
3. Progress bar: should fill as you progress
4. Results: after the last question, you'll see:
   - Your dish emoji
   - Your personality type (e.g., INTJ, ENFP)
   - A description of your dish match
   - Trait tags
5. Restart: click "Take Quiz Again" to retry

## Tips for Testing

- Try different answer combinations to see different results
- Test on mobile by accessing `http://[your-computer-ip]:8000` from your phone
- Check the browser console (F12) for any JavaScript errors

To stop the server later, let me know and I can help.

Is the quiz working as expected?

## Changes made

### 1. Storyline
- Each question includes a story context
- Narrative follows a food adventure through Singapore's hawker centers
- Questions are integrated into the story (e.g., "Welcome to Singapore! üå¥", "You arrive at a bustling hawker center!")

### 2. Color scheme
- Background: soft pink ‚Üí peach ‚Üí light blue gradient
- Buttons: pink to peach gradient with soft shadows
- Story text boxes: pastel backgrounds with a pink accent border
- Progress bar: pink ‚Üí peach ‚Üí blue gradient
- Trait tags: colorful gradient with soft shadows

### 3. Visual updates
- Story text appears in a styled box above each question
- Italicized story text for emphasis
- Softer hover effects with pastel backgrounds
- More rounded corners and softer shadows

The quiz now has a cohesive narrative and a softer, more playful look. Refresh your browser to see the changes.

The storyline guides users through:
1. Arriving in Singapore
2. Exploring hawker centers
3. Meeting friendly hawkers
4. Making food decisions
5. Planning food adventures
6. Learning about cooking
7. Organizing food gatherings
8. Reflecting on the day

Try it out and let me know if you want any adjustments.

Implement a Cuter Font:**<br/><br/>Selecting an appropriate font can significantly influence the game's aesthetic. Here are some playful and legible fonts you might consider:<br/><br/>- **Andy:** A casual script font that mimics handwriting, offering a friendly and informal feel. ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_%28typeface%29?utm_source=openai))<br/><br/>- **Amaranth:** A slightly rounded sans-serif font with a playful touch, suitable for both headings and body text. ([canva.com](https://www.canva.com/learn/web-fonts/?utm_source=openai))<br/><br/>- **Cabin:** An elegant sans-serif font that pairs well with calligraphic headlines, adding a touch of sophistication. ([canva.com](https://www.canva.com/learn/web-fonts/?utm_source=openai))<br/><br/>To apply a new font:<br/><br/>- **Include the Font:** If using a web font, link it in your HTML's `<head>` section. For example, to use Amaranth from Google Fonts:<br/><br/>  <br/>```html<br/>  <link href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/css2?family=Amaranth:wght@400;700&display=swap" rel="stylesheet"><br/>  ```<br/><br/><br/>- **Apply the Font in CSS:** In your CSS file, set the desired font for your elements:<br/><br/>  <br/>```css<br/>  body \{<br/>    font-family: 'Amaranth', sans-serif;<br/>  \}<br/>  ```<br/><br/><br/>**2. Design a Mobile-Friendly Layout:**<br/><br/>Ensuring your game is responsive and displays well on various devices, especially mobile phones, is crucial. Here's how to achieve that:<br/><br/>- **Use a Responsive Meta Tag:** Add the following line to your HTML's `<head>` section to control the viewport settings:<br/><br/>  <br/>```html<br/>  <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1"><br/>  ```<br/><br/><br/>- **Implement Flexible Grids and Layouts:** Utilize CSS Grid or Flexbox to create layouts that adapt to different screen sizes. For example, using Flexbox:<br/><br/>  <br/>```css<br/>  .container \{<br/>    display: flex;<br/>    flex-direction: column;<br/>    align-items: center;<br/>  \}<br/>  ```<br/><br/><br/>- **Apply Media Queries:** Use media queries to adjust styles for various screen sizes. For instance:<br/><br/>  <br/>```css<br/>  @media (min-width: 600px) \{<br/>    .container \{<br/>      flex-direction: row;<br/>    \}<br/>  \}<br/>  ```<br/><br/><br/>This approach ensures that your layout is flexible and adapts to different devices. ([developer.mozilla.org](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Learn_web_development/Core/CSS_layout/Responsive_Design?utm_source=openai))<br/><br/>**3. Add Cute Graphics:**<br/><br/>Incorporating charming visuals can make your game more engaging:<br/><br/>- **Source Appropriate Images:** Use platforms like [Unsplash](https://unsplash.com/) or [Pexels](https://www.pexels.com/) to find free, high-quality images.<br/><br/>- **Optimize Images for Web:** Ensure images are optimized for faster loading times. Tools like [TinyPNG](https://tinypng.com/) can help compress images without significant quality loss.<br/><br/>- **Implement Responsive Images:** Use CSS to make images responsive:<br/><br/>  <br/>```css<br/>  img \{<br/>    max-width: 100%;<br/>    height: auto;<br/>  \}<br/>  ```<br/><br/><br/>By following these steps, you can enhance the visual appeal and usability of your personality test game, making it more engaging for users across various devices. |

## Changes made

### 1. Cute pixelated font
- Added **Pixelify Sans** from Google Fonts
- Applied to all text (headings, buttons, options)
- Uppercase styling for buttons

### 2. Phone-like layout
- Narrow container: max-width 375px (phone width)
- Phone frame effect: black border with white inner border
- Centered on all screen sizes
- Mint green background (#a8e6cf)

### 3. Cute graphics
- SVG illustrations on the start screen:
  - Cute Laksa (left) ‚Äî bowl with a face and legs
  - Cute Chilli Crab (center) ‚Äî red crab with claws
  - Cute Chicken Rice (right) ‚Äî plate with a face
- Simple sky and grass background
- Characters have faces, eyes, smiles, and stick legs

### 4. Retro game styling
- Buttons: yellow with black borders and box shadows
- Options: white with black borders and 3D shadow effect
- Sharp corners (no border-radius)
- Press-down button animations

The quiz now matches the vegetal style: pixelated font, phone-like layout, and cute dish characters. Refresh your browser to see the changes.

---


## Changes made

### 1. More casual, food-focused questions
- Rewrote all 10 questions to be less structured and less obviously a personality test
- Questions focus on food choices and hawker center scenarios
- Examples:
  - "What catches your eye first?" instead of "What's your first move?"
  - "Your food arrives! It looks amazing. You take your first bite..." instead of asking about personality traits
  - More natural, conversational flow

### 2. Enhanced results screen
- Tagline: Each dish has a tagline (e.g., "The Mastermind - Complex, bold, and unforgettable")
- Strengths: 4 strengths per dish with checkmarks
- Weaknesses: 3 weaknesses per dish with bullet points
- Most compatible: Top 3 compatible dishes with emojis

### 3. Removed personality type display
- Removed the INTJ/ENFP/etc. display from results
- Results focus on the dish name and characteristics

### 4. Styling
- Two-column layout for strengths/weaknesses (stacks on mobile)
- Color-coded borders (green for strengths, pink for weaknesses)
- Compatible dishes shown as cards with emojis

The quiz now reads as a food adventure rather than a personality test, while still mapping to the 16 types. Refresh your browser to see the changes.

## Changes made

### 1. More Singaporean taglines
Updated all 16 taglines to be more casual and Singaporean, using Singlish phrases and local references:
- "Shiok ah! Deep and complex, just like your flavor" (Bak Kut Teh)
- "Power lah! Not shy to be the star" (Chilli Crab)
- "Anything also can mix - creative and unpredictable" (Rojak)
- "Everyone also like - the classic that unites us all" (Hainanese Chicken Rice)
- "Steady lah - reliable and always on point" (Char Kway Teow)
- "Complete package - everything also have, all balanced" (Nasi Lemak)
- And more

### 2. Mobile-optimized results screen
- Reduced padding: `15px 10px` for results screen
- Smaller font sizes:
  - Dish emoji: `4em` (was 5em)
  - Heading: `1.5em` (was 1.8em)
  - Tagline: `0.9em` with better line-height
  - Description: `0.85em`
  - List items: `0.75em`
- Tighter spacing: reduced margins and gaps throughout
- Scrollable: added `overflow-y: auto` and `max-height: 100vh` to results screen
- Strengths/weaknesses: already stack on mobile (single column)

The results screen should now fit better on mobile, and the taglines are more Singaporean and less cringe. Refresh your browser to see the changes.

+

+ // Check for saved results on page load
+ function checkForSavedResults() {
+     const savedPersonality = localStorage.getItem(&#39;letsmakan_result&#39;);
+     if (savedPersonality &amp;&amp; personalityDishes[savedPersonality]) {
+         const dish = personalityDishes[savedPersonality];
+         startScreen.classList.remove(&#39;active&#39;);
+         quizScreen.classList.remove(&#39;active&#39;);
+         resultsScreen.classList.add(&#39;active&#39;);
+         renderResults(dish);
+     }
+ }
+ 
+ // Initialize on page load
+ document.addEventListener(&#39;DOMContentLoaded&#39;, () =&gt; {
+     createStartGraphics();
+     checkForSavedResults();
+ });

Added localStorage persistence for quiz results. Changes:

## Changes Made

### 1. **Save Results to localStorage**
- When the quiz completes, the personality type is saved to localStorage
- Also saves a timestamp for potential future use

### 2. **Restore Results on Page Load**
- On page load, checks for saved results
- If found, automatically shows the results screen instead of the start screen
- Results persist across page refreshes

### 3. **Clear Results When Starting New Quiz**
- Clears saved results when clicking "Start" to begin a new quiz
- Clears saved results when clicking "Start Over" from the results screen
- Ensures a fresh start for each new quiz attempt

### 4. **Refactored Code**
- Extracted result rendering into a separate `renderResults()` function
- Used by both `showResults()` and `checkForSavedResults()`
- Cleaner and more maintainable

Now when you:
- Complete the quiz ‚Üí Results are saved
- Refresh the page ‚Üí Results are automatically restored and displayed
- Start a new quiz ‚Üí Saved results are cleared

Refresh your browser and complete the quiz to test. The results should persist after refresh.

## Changes Made

### 1. **Updated HTML**
- Replaced the `<div id="start-graphics">` with an `<img>` tag pointing to `img/hawker.jpg`

### 2. **Updated CSS**
- Replaced `.cute-graphics` styles with `.hawker-image` styles
- Applied the same retro game aesthetic:
  - Black border (`3px solid #333`)
  - Box shadow (`4px 4px 0 #333`)
  - Responsive sizing (width: 100%, height: auto)
  - Object-fit: cover to maintain aspect ratio

### 3. **Cleaned up JavaScript**
- Removed the entire `createStartGraphics()` function (200+ lines of SVG code)
- Updated the initialization to remove the graphics creation call

The hawker center image now appears on the start screen with the same retro styling as the rest of the quiz. Refresh your browser to see the change.

+             bpcEye2.setAttribute(&#39;cx&#39;, &#39;55&#39;);

+             g.appendChild(bpcEye2);
+             // Smile
+             const bpcSmile = document.createElementNS(&#39;http://www.w3.org/2000/svg&#39;, &#39;path&#39;);
+             bpcSmile.setAttribute(&#39;d&#39;, &#39;M 42 58 Q 50 63 58 58&#39;);
+             bpcSmile.setAttribute(&#39;stroke&#39;, &#39;#FFD700&#39;);
+             bpcSmile.setAttribute(&#39;stroke-width&#39;, &#39;2&#39;);
+             bpcSmile.setAttribute(&#39;fill&#39;, &#39;none&#39;);
+             g.appendChild(bpcSmile);
+             // Legs
+             for (let i = 0; i &lt; 4; i++) {
+                 const leg = document.createElementNS(&#39;http://www.w3.org/2000/svg&#39;, &#39;line&#39;);
+                 leg.setAttribute(&#39;x1&#39;, 40 + i * 5);
+                 leg.setAttribute(&#39;y1&#39;, &#39;73&#39;);
+                 leg.setAttribute(&#39;x2&#39;, 35 + i * 5);

+             }
+             break;

Replaced emojis with custom SVG illustrations for all 16 dishes.

## Changes Made

### 1. **Created `createDishIllustration()` Function**
   - Generates SVG illustrations for each dish
   - Each dish has a unique design with:
     - Anthropomorphic faces (eyes and smiles)
     - Dish-specific elements (bowls, plates, ingredients)
     - Colors matching the dish
   - Examples:
     - **Bak Kut Teh**: Bowl with soup and a face
     - **Chilli Crab**: Red crab with claws and legs
     - **Kaya Toast**: Two toast slices with kaya filling
     - **Ice Kacang**: Layered ice with colorful toppings
     - And 12 more unique designs

### 2. **Updated Results Display**
   - Main dish illustration: 120x120px SVG at the top
   - Compatible dishes: Smaller 40x40px illustrations next to each compatible dish name
   - Illustrations are dynamically generated when results are shown

### 3. **Updated CSS**
   - Added styling for `.dish-illustration-container` and `.dish-illustration`
   - Styled `.compatible-illustration` for smaller compatible dish icons
   - Removed unused CSS classes

The illustrations match the retro pixelated aesthetic and give each dish a distinct personality. Refresh your browser and complete the quiz to see them in action.

Updated the "Most Compatible With" section to display in 3 columns instead of rows.

## Changes Made

### 1. **Layout Change**
   - Changed `.compatible-dishes` from `flex-direction: column` to `flex-direction: row`
   - Added `justify-content: center` to center the items
   - Each item now uses `flex: 1` to take equal space

### 2. **Item Layout**
   - Each `.compatible-item` now uses `flex-direction: column` (illustration on top, name below)
   - Centered alignment for both illustration and text
   - Adjusted padding and gap for the new layout

### 3. **Text Styling**
   - Reduced font size slightly to `0.75em` for better fit
   - Added `text-align: center` and `word-wrap: break-word` for better text handling

### 4. **Mobile Responsive**
   - On screens smaller than 600px, it reverts to a vertical column layout
   - Items switch back to horizontal (illustration and name side-by-side) on mobile

The compatible dishes now display in a 3-column grid on larger screens, with each dish showing its illustration above its name. Refresh your browser to see the change.

+     return imageMap[dishName] || &#39;img/chicken_rice.png&#39;; // Fallback to chicken rice if image not found
+ }
+ 
+ // Function to create dish image element
  function createDishIllustration(dishName) {
+     const img = document.createElement(&#39;img&#39;);
+     img.src = getDishImagePath(dishName);
+     img.alt = dishName;
+     img.className = &#39;dish-illustration&#39;;
+     img.setAttribute(&#39;width&#39;, &#39;120&#39;);
+     img.setAttribute(&#39;height&#39;, &#39;120&#39;);
+     return img;
+ }
+ 
+ // Old SVG function - keeping for reference but not used
+ function createDishIllustrationSVG(dishName) {
      const svg = document.createElementNS(&#39;http://www.w3.org/2000/svg&#39;, &#39;svg&#39;);
      svg.setAttribute(&#39;viewBox&#39;, &#39;0 0 100 100&#39;);
```

</details>

</tool-use>

Updated the code to use images instead of SVG illustrations. Summary:

## Changes Made

### 1. **Created Image Mapping Function**
   - Added `getDishImagePath()` that maps each dish name to its image file
   - Uses `img/chicken_rice.png` for "Hainanese Chicken Rice" (as you specified)
   - Maps all other dishes to their expected image paths (e.g., `img/bak_kut_teh.png`, `img/laksa.png`, etc.)

### 2. **Updated Illustration Function**
   - Replaced the SVG creation with an image element creation
   - The function now creates `<img>` elements instead of SVG
   - Added error handling: if an image file doesn't exist, it shows a placeholder with the dish name

### 3. **Updated CSS**
   - Added `object-fit: cover` to ensure images display properly
   - Added `border-radius` for rounded corners
   - Updated compatible illustration styles to work with images instead of SVG

### 4. **Image Paths Expected**
The code expects these image files in the `img/` folder:
- `chicken_rice.png` (already exists)
- `bak_kut_teh.png`
- `kaya_toast.png`
- `chilli_crab.png`
- `rojak.png`
- `laksa.png`
- `ice_kacang.png`
- `satay.png`
- `char_kway_teow.png`
- `bak_chor_mee.png`
- `nasi_lemak.png`
- `popiah.png`
- `hokkien_mee.png`
- `oyster_omelette.png`
- `black_pepper_crab.png`
- `murtabak.png`

Until you add the images, the code will show placeholder images with the dish name. Once you add the actual image files to the `img/` folder, they'll automatically be used.

Fixed the cropping issue. Changes:

## Changes Made

1. **Removed fixed width/height attributes from JavaScript** ‚Äî The code was setting `width="120"` and `height="120"` directly on the image element, which forced a square size and caused cropping. Removed those attributes.

2. **Updated CSS to use max-width/max-height** ‚Äî Changed from fixed dimensions to `max-width: 120px` and `max-height: 120px` with `width: auto` and `height: auto`. This lets the image maintain its aspect ratio.

3. **Added overflow: visible to container** ‚Äî Ensures the container doesn't clip the image.

4. **Fixed compatible dish images** ‚Äî Removed fixed width/height attributes and applied the same max-width/max-height approach.

The chicken rice image (and all other dish images) should now display fully without being cut off. The image will scale to fit within the 120px maximum while maintaining its aspect ratio, and `object-fit: contain` ensures the entire image is visible.

Updated the CSS so non-square images display fully. Changes:

## Changes Made

1. **Removed `object-fit: contain`** ‚Äî Not needed when using `width: auto` and `height: auto`. It only applies when dimensions are fixed.

2. **Set max-width and max-height to 150px** ‚Äî Increased from 120px to give more room while still constraining size.

3. **Added `display: block`** ‚Äî Prevents inline spacing issues that could affect layout.

4. **Added `min-height: 150px` to container** ‚Äî Ensures the container has enough vertical space for taller images.

The image will now:
- Maintain its natural aspect ratio (not forced into a square)
- Scale down proportionally if it exceeds 150px in width or height
- Display fully without being cropped

The chicken rice image (and all other dish images) should now display completely, regardless of whether they're square, wide, or tall. Refresh your browser to see the change.

---


Fixed the container constraints. The `.compatible-illustration` container had fixed `width: 40px` and `height: 40px`, forcing a square. Changes:

## Changes Made

1. **Changed container from fixed to minimum dimensions** ‚Äî Changed `width: 40px` and `height: 40px` to `min-width: 40px` and `min-height: 40px`. This allows the container to expand if needed while maintaining a minimum size.

2. **Removed `object-fit: contain`** ‚Äî Not needed when using `width: auto` and `height: auto`. Removed it to let images display at their natural aspect ratio.

3. **Added `display: block`** ‚Äî Prevents inline spacing issues.

The images should now display fully without being cropped. The container will adapt to the image's aspect ratio while respecting the max-width and max-height constraints.

If you still see `width="40" height="40"` attributes in the browser inspector, it might be cached HTML. Try:
1. Hard refresh (Ctrl+Shift+R or Cmd+Shift+R)
2. Clear browser cache
3. Check the actual HTML source to confirm the attributes aren't there

The CSS changes should prevent cropping regardless of those attributes.

Removed the mobile CSS that forced compatible dishes into a vertical column. They now display in a horizontal row (3 columns) on both mobile and laptop.

## Changes Made

**Removed mobile-specific overrides** ‚Äî Deleted the CSS rules that changed:
- `.compatible-dishes` from `flex-direction: row` to `flex-direction: column` on mobile
- `.compatible-item` from `flex-direction: column` to `flex-direction: row` on mobile

Now the compatible dishes will:
- Display in 3 columns (horizontal) on all screen sizes
- Keep the same layout on mobile and laptop
- Each dish shows its image on top and name below within each column

The layout is now consistent across all devices. Refresh your browser to see the change.

Updated all 16 personality types with more casual, relatable strengths and weaknesses. Examples:

## Examples of the New Style

**Strengths:**
- "Always makes the first move"
- "Good leader"
- "Comes up with the wackiest ideas but it works out"
- "Life of the party"
- "Can fix anything with Google"
- "Never late for anything"

**Weaknesses:**
- "Too scared to ask their crush out"
- "Room is a mess but knows where everything is"
- "Starts 10 projects, finishes 2"
- "Forgets to reply messages"
- "Procrastinates until the last minute"

The new strengths and weaknesses are:
- More casual and conversational
- Relatable and specific
- Less formal
- Still accurate to each personality type

All 16 types now use this style. Refresh your browser and complete the quiz to see the updated results.

Removed duplicates. Each personality type now has unique strengths and weaknesses. Changes:

## Fixed Duplicates

1. **"Always makes the first move"** ‚Äî kept for ENTJ, changed ESFJ to "Initiates group activities"
2. **"Too scared to ask their crush out"** ‚Äî kept for INFP, changed:
   - ISTJ ‚Üí "Too scared to try new things"
   - ISFP ‚Üí "Too scared to speak up sometimes"
3. **"Can fix anything"** ‚Äî INTP has "Can fix anything with Google" (unique), ISTP has "Can fix anything" (unique)
4. **"Creative and artsy" vs "Super creative and artsy"** ‚Äî kept as is (different enough)

All 16 personality types now have unique strengths and weaknesses. Each trait appears only once across all types, making each result more distinct.

Updated the question to have 3 more balanced options:

## Changes Made

1. **Option 1**: "Stay longer! Chat with friends and maybe try a dessert" ‚Äî for extroverted, social types (ENFJ, ENFP, ESFJ, ESFP, ENTP, ESTP)

2. **Option 2**: "Time to head home while the experience is still fresh in my mind" ‚Äî for introverted types (all I types). This frames leaving as intentional and reflective rather than just wanting to be alone.

3. **Option 3**: "Stay a bit more but let's plan what to try next time" ‚Äî for organized extroverts (ENTJ, ESTJ). This balances staying with planning.

This makes the choices more balanced and appealing, so it better tests personality types rather than just "fun vs boring". The second option now sounds thoughtful rather than antisocial, and the third gives a middle ground for those who want to stay but also plan ahead.

Updated the options to be more specific and personality-revealing:

## Changes Made

1. **Option 1**: "Ooh sounds good! Let me go check it out now" ‚Äî Shows spontaneity and immediate action (ENFP, ESFP, ENTP, ESTP, ENFJ, ESFJ)

2. **Option 2**: "Hmm, maybe they're exaggerating. I'll stick to what I know works" ‚Äî Shows skepticism and preference for reliability (ISTJ, ESTJ, INTJ, ENTJ)

3. **Option 3**: "Interesting... let me observe the stall first and see what others are saying" ‚Äî Shows cautious observation and information-gathering (INTP, INFP, INFJ, ISFJ, ISFP, ISTP)

These options are more specific and reveal different traits:
- **Spontaneity vs. caution** ‚Äî immediate action vs. gathering information
- **Trust vs. skepticism** ‚Äî believing recommendations vs. being skeptical
- **Action vs. observation** ‚Äî jumping in vs. watching first

This should better differentiate personality types than the previous generic options.

Updated the question to be more realistic and natural. It now has 2 options:

## Changes Made

1. **Option 1**: "Ooh sounds good! Let me go check it out now" ‚Äî for spontaneous, action-oriented types (ENFP, ESFP, ENTP, ESTP, ENFJ, ESFJ)

2. **Option 2**: "Interesting... I'll probably forget about it though" ‚Äî for more introverted, analytical types (ISTJ, ESTJ, INTJ, ENTJ, INTP, INFP, INFJ, ISFJ, ISFP, ISTP)

This is more realistic and natural. The second option reflects a common response: acknowledging it but likely forgetting. It still differentiates personality types by testing:
- **Spontaneity vs. passivity** ‚Äî immediate action vs. acknowledging but not acting
- **Extroversion vs. introversion** ‚Äî engaging vs. internal processing

All 16 types are included exactly once.
